items.prompt: If you had 60 minutes to prove you can run this organization, what decisions do you insist on making personally vs systematizing?

answers.text: Disciplined build: sustainable contender via roster pipeline, process, and situational excellence.
Aggressive window play: trade up/pay premiums when the opportunity is real; accept risk.
Stay ahead of the league cycle: adapt annually, self-scout relentlessly, evolve schematically.
Succession architecture: develop staff, preserve system language, and avoid resets when talent departs.

items.prompt: What is the clearest line between your football identity and your roster requirements—what must always be true for your scheme to stay viable?

answers.text: Build a scripted plan with built-in answers (hots, screens, checks) and self-scout counters weekly.
Stress defenses with formation, motion, and spacing to force reveals; adjust calls off reactions.
Attack aggressively with pressure/shot concepts to dictate terms; accept higher variance.
Keep concepts tight and execution-driven; win on fundamentals and communication.

items.prompt: When your evaluation disagrees with scouting, what is the escalation path to a final decision, and how do you prevent factions?

answers.text: Define decision rights explicitly and run a shared weekly cadence; align in writing on priorities.
HC-led model: football decisions flow through the head coach; partners advise but HC owns outcomes.
Collaborative model: joint problem-solving with GM, clear escalation path, and unified messaging.
Keep lanes clean: ownership sets resources/expectations, GM builds roster, coaches teach and manage games.

Change levers quickly: role shifts, workload/practice tweaks, and schematic patches to stop the bleeding.
